arXiv:2403.09332v1 [astro-ph.EP] 14 Mar 2024

A secular solar system resonance that disrupts the dominant cycle in Earthâ€™s orbital eccentricity (g2subscriptğ‘”2g_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--g5subscriptğ‘”5g_{5}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT): Implications for astrochronology

Abstract

The planetsâ€™ gravitational interaction causes rhythmic changes in Earthâ€™s orbital parameters (also called MilankoviÄ‡ cycles), which have powerful applications in geology and astrochronology. For instance, the primary astronomical eccentricity cycle due to the secular frequency term (g2subscriptğ‘”2g_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--g5subscriptğ‘”5g_{5}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) (âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼405 kyr in the recent past) utilized in deep-time analyses is dominated by Venusâ€™ and Jupiterâ€™s orbits, aka long eccentricity cycle. The widely accepted and long-held view is that (g2subscriptğ‘”2g_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--g5subscriptğ‘”5g_{5}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) was practically stable in the past and may hence be used as a â€œmetronomeâ€ to reconstruct accurate ages and chronologies. However, using state-of-the-art integrations of the solar system, we show here that (g2subscriptğ‘”2g_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--g5subscriptğ‘”5g_{5}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) can become unstable over long time scales, without major changes in, or destabilization of, planetary orbits. The (g2subscriptğ‘”2g_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--g5subscriptğ‘”5g_{5}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) disruption is due to the secular resonance Ïƒ12=(g1âˆ’g2)+(s1âˆ’s2)subscriptğœ12subscriptğ‘”1subscriptğ‘”2subscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2\mbox{$\sigma_{12}$}=(g_{1}-g_{2})+(s_{1}-s_{2})italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), a major contributor to solar system chaos. We demonstrate that entering/exiting the Ïƒ12subscriptğœ12\sigma_{12}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT resonance is a common phenomenon on long time scales, occurring in âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼40% of our solutions. During Ïƒ12subscriptğœ12\sigma_{12}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-resonance episodes, (g2subscriptğ‘”2g_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--g5subscriptğ‘”5g_{5}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) is very weak or absent and Earthâ€™s orbital eccentricity and climate-forcing spectrum are unrecognizable compared to the recent past. Our results have fundamental implications for geology and astrochronology, as well as climate forcing because the paradigm that the longest MilankoviÄ‡ cycle dominates Earthâ€™s astronomical forcing, is stable, and has a period of âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼405 kyr requires revision.

1 Introduction

Laying the foundations of chaos theory, Henri PoincarÃ© wrote: â€œIt may happen that small differences in the initial conditions produce very great ones in the final phenomena. A small error in the former will produce an enormous error in the latter. Prediction becomes impossible â€¦â€¦\ldotsâ€¦â€ (PoincarÃ©, 1914). In reference to the solar system, the sensitivity to initial conditions is indeed a key feature of the large-scale dynamical chaos in the system, which has been confirmed numerically (Sussman & Wisdom, 1988; Laskar, 1989; Ito & Tanikawa, 2002; Morbidelli, 2002; Varadi et al., 2003; Batygin & Laughlin, 2008; Zeebe, 2015; Brown & Rein, 2020; Abbot et al., 2023). Dynamical chaos affects the secular frequencies gisubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–g_{i}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see Appendix A), where the terms (g4subscriptğ‘”4g_{4}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--g3subscriptğ‘”3g_{3}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and (s4subscriptğ‘ 4s_{4}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--s3subscriptğ‘ 3s_{3}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), for instance, show chaotic behavior already on a 50-Myr time scale. As a result, astronomical solutions diverge around t=Â±50ğ‘¡plus-or-minus50t=\pm 50italic_t = Â± 50 Myr, which fundamentally prevents identifying a unique solution on time scales âˆ¼>superscriptsimilar-to\stackrel{{\scriptstyle>}}{{\sim}}\ start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG âˆ¼ end_ARG start_ARG > end_ARG end_RELOP1088{}^{8}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 8 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT y (Laskar et al., 2004; Zeebe, 2017; Zeebe & Lourens, 2019). The chaos therefore not only severely limits our understanding and ability to reconstruct and predict the solar systemâ€™s history and long-term future, it also imposes strict limits on geological and astrochronological applications such as developing a fully calibrated astronomical time scale beyond âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼50 Ma (for recent efforts, see Zeebe & Lourens, 2019, 2022). In contrast to these limitations (largely due to unstable terms such as (g4subscriptğ‘”4g_{4}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--g3subscriptğ‘”3g_{3}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and (s4subscriptğ‘ 4s_{4}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--s3subscriptğ‘ 3s_{3}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT)), another frequency term appears more promising as it shows more stable behavior. For example, it has hitherto been assumed that (g2subscriptğ‘”2g_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--g5subscriptğ‘”5g_{5}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) was practically stable in the past and has been suggested for use as a â€œmetronomeâ€ in deep-time geological applications, i.e., far exceeding 50 Ma (Laskar et al., 2004; Kent et al., 2018; Spalding et al., 2018; Meyers & Malinverno, 2018; Montenari, 2018; Lantink et al., 2019; De Vleeschouwer et al., 2024). The (g2subscriptğ‘”2g_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--g5subscriptğ‘”5g_{5}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) cycle, which is the dominant term in Earthâ€™s orbital eccentricity in the recent past (âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼405 kyr, see Fig. 1a) may thus have been regarded as an island of stability in a sea of chaos. However, we show in this contribution that also (g2subscriptğ‘”2g_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--g5subscriptğ‘”5g_{5}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) can become unstable over long time scales.

Solar system dynamics affect Earthâ€™s orbital evolution, as well as Earthâ€™s climate, which is paced by astronomical cycles on time scales âˆ¼>superscriptsimilar-to\stackrel{{\scriptstyle>}}{{\sim}}\ start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG âˆ¼ end_ARG start_ARG > end_ARG end_RELOP10 kyr. The cycles include precession and obliquity cycles of Earthâ€™s spin axis (âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼20 and 40 kyr in the recent past), and the short and long eccentricity cycles (âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼100 and 405 kyr, see Figs. 1a and 6) (MilankoviÄ‡, 1941; Montenari, 2018). Orbital eccentricity is controlled by the solar systemâ€™s orbital dynamics and is the focus of this study. The primary tuning target used in astrochronology and cyclostratigraphy for deep-time stratigraphic age models is the long eccentricity cycle (LEC) because it is widely assumed to be stable in the past (see above). Dynamically, Earthâ€™s orbital eccentricity and inclination cycles originate from combinations of the solar systemâ€™s fundamental frequencies, called gğ‘”gitalic_g- and sğ‘ sitalic_s-frequencies (or modes), loosely related to the apsidal and nodal precession of the planetary orbits (Fig. A.1). The LEC is dominated by Venusâ€™ and Jupiterâ€™s orbits, viz., (g2âˆ’g5)g_{2}-g_{5})italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), or g25subscriptğ‘”25g_{25}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 25 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for short, and represents the strongest cycle in Earthâ€™s eccentricity spectrum in the recent past (see Figs. 1 and 6). Assuming a stable LEC may appear plausible because Jupiter (dominating g5subscriptğ‘”5g_{5}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) is the most massive planet and less susceptible to perturbations. Astronomical computations have confirmed g5subscriptğ‘”5g_{5}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s stability and hitherto did not indicate instabilities in g25subscriptğ‘”25g_{25}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 25 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Berger, 1984; Quinn et al., 1991; Varadi et al., 2003; Laskar et al., 2004; Zeebe, 2017; Spalding et al., 2018; Zeebe & Lourens, 2022). However, compared to g5subscriptğ‘”5g_{5}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, g2subscriptğ‘”2g_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s long-term stability is less certain but has been overlooked so far. The long-term stability of g25subscriptğ‘”25g_{25}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 25 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the LEC is critical for, e.g., climate forcing/insolation, constructing accurate age models and chronologies, expanding the evidence for the astronomical theory of climate into the more distant past, extending the astronomically calibrated geological time scale into deep time, and more (see discussion). Below we show that the LEC can become unstable over long-time scales owing to g2subscriptğ‘”2g_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, without major changes in, or destabilization of, planetary orbits. Orbital destabilization is a known, separate dynamical phenomenon relevant to the future, see below.

For the present study, we performed state-of-the-art solar system integrations, including the eight planets and Pluto, a lunar contribution, general relativity, the solar quadrupole moment, and solar mass loss (see Section 2) (Zeebe, 2017; Zeebe & Lourens, 2019; Zeebe, 2022, 2023). Initial conditions at time t0subscriptğ‘¡0t_{0}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT were taken from the latest JPL ephemeris DE441 (Park et al., 2021) and the equations of motion were numerically integrated to t=âˆ’3.5ğ‘¡3.5t=-3.5italic_t = - 3.5 Gyr (beyond âˆ’3.53.5-3.5- 3.5 Gyr parameters such as the lunar distance have large uncertainties, see Section 2). Owing to solar system chaos, the solutions diverge around t=âˆ’50ğ‘¡50t=-50italic_t = - 50 Myr, which prevents identifying a unique solution on time scales âˆ¼>superscriptsimilar-to\stackrel{{\scriptstyle>}}{{\sim}}\ start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG âˆ¼ end_ARG start_ARG > end_ARG end_RELOP1088{}^{8}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 8 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT y (see above). Hence we present results from long-term ensemble integrations to explore the possible solution/phase space of the system (see Section 2). Importantly, because of the chaos, each âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼108superscript10810^{8}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT y interval of the integrations represents a snapshot of the systemâ€™s general/possible behavior that is largely independent of the actual numerical time of a particular solution (provided here that t<âˆ’Ï„12ğ‘¡subscriptğœ12t<-\mbox{$\tau_{12}$}italic_t < - italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Ï„12subscriptğœ12\tau_{12}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is of order 108superscript10810^{8}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 109superscript10910^{9}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 9 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT y, see below). In other words, a numerical solutionâ€™s behavior around, say, t=âˆ’1.5ğ‘¡1.5t=-1.5italic_t = - 1.5 Gyr may represent the actual solar system around t=âˆ’600ğ‘¡600t=-600italic_t = - 600 Myr and so on.

2 Methods

2.1 Solar System Integrations

Solar system integrations were performed following our earlier work (Zeebe, 2017; Zeebe & Lourens, 2019; Zeebe, 2022) with our integrator package orbitN (v1.0) (Zeebe, 2023), using a symplectic integrator and Jacobi coordinates (Wisdom & Holman, 1991; Zeebe, 2015a). The open source code is available at zenodo.org/records/8021040 and github.com/rezeebe/orbitN. The methods used here and our integrator package have been extensively tested and compared against other studies (Zeebe, 2017; Zeebe & Lourens, 2019; Zeebe, 2022, 2023). For the present study, we also included simulations with an independent integrator package (HNBody) (Rauch & Hamilton, 2002) and found the same dynamical behavior. All simulations include contributions from general relativity, available in orbitN as Post-Newtonian effects due to the dominant mass. The Earth-Moon system was modeled as a gravitational quadrupole (Quinn et al., 1991; Varadi et al., 2003; Zeebe, 2017, 2023). Initial conditions for the positions and velocities of the planets and Pluto were generated from the latest JPL ephemeris DE441 (Park et al., 2021) using the SPICE toolkit for Matlab. Coordinates were obtained at JD2451545.0 in the ECLIPJ2000 reference frame and subsequently rotated to account for the solar quadrupole moment (J2subscriptğ½2J_{2}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) alignment with the solar rotation axis (Zeebe, 2017). 2.3 Past Earth-Moon distance

Our integrations included a lunar contribution, i.e., a gravitational quadrupole model of the Earth-Moon system (Quinn et al., 1991; Varadi et al., 2003; Zeebe, 2017, 2023). In the present context, the lunar contribution has a relatively small effect on the overall dynamics, yet the integration requires the Earth-Moon distance (Rğ‘…Ritalic_R) as parameter at a given time in the past. Moreover, because there is no simple one-to-one relationship between a single mode and a single inner planet (the motion is a superposition of all modes), resonances (say Ïƒiâ¢jsubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘—\sigma_{ij}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with i,j=1,â€¦â¢4formulae-sequenceğ‘–ğ‘—1â€¦4i,j=1,\ldots 4italic_i , italic_j = 1 , â€¦ 4, iâ‰ jğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq jitalic_i â‰  italic_j) affect the entire inner solar system. Here, we have only investigated Ïƒ12subscriptğœ12\sigma_{12}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s effect on (g2subscriptğ‘”2g_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâˆ’--g5subscriptğ‘”5g_{5}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and Earthâ€™s orbital eccentricity. Future work should explore whether there are other important, yet unknown, effects of Ïƒ12subscriptğœ12\sigma_{12}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (and other resonances) on the dynamics and planetary climates in the inner solar system.

Our results have fundamental implications for, e.g., current astrochronologic and cyclostratigraphic practices, which are based on the paradigm that the LEC is stable, dominates the eccentricity spectrum, and has a period of âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼405 kyr. Given our findings that the Ïƒ12subscriptğœ12\sigma_{12}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT resonance is a common phenomenon (occurring in âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼40% of our solutions), the assumption of a stable 405 kyr cycle in deep time can no longer be made. Specifically, the possibility of an unstable period and weakened LEC amplitude requires rethinking of currently employed strategies for building accurate and high-resolution (â€˜floatingâ€™ or radio-isotopically anchored) astrochronologic age models. The presumed 405-kyr â€œmetronomeâ€ was particularly important for constructing pre-Cenozoic age models, where reliable astronomical solutions are absent owing to solar system chaos. Deep-time astrochronologies have thus far critically relied on identification of the LEC because it is the only MilankoviÄ‡ cycle whose period has been widely regarded as stable (Laskar et al., 2004; Kent et al., 2018; Spalding et al., 2018) and of sufficiently large amplitude to be typically expressed in sedimentary sequences. Our results indicate that, prior to several hundred Myrs in the past, the LEC may have become unstable over multi-million year intervals. Notably, on these time scales the periods of other critical MilankoviÄ‡ parameters (climatic precession and obliquity) are also more uncertain due to changes in the Earth-Moon systemâ€™s tidal evolution.

Does the presently explored geologic record provide examples consistent with our astronomical calculations? We note here a recently discovered section in the âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼2.46 Ga Joffre Member of the Brockman Iron Formation (Joffre Falls, Western Australia), in which a dominant short eccentricity cycle was reported (âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼100 kyr), compared to a relatively weak expression at the scale of the interpreted LEC (Lantink et al., 2022) (see Fig. D.1). The interpreted eccentricity modulation pattern in the Joffre Falls section differs from typical Cenozoic precession-eccentricity dominated records, which often display a strong 1:4 hierarchy of long vs. short eccentricity cycles. One first-order interpretation for the unusual bundling pattern is a complex nonlinear response of the paleoclimate and/or sedimentary system to orbital forcing, which is still poorly understood for the ancient deposits. Yet, given our findings, a fundamentally different pattern of Earthâ€™s orbital eccentricity variations (i.e., a weakened LEC) at the time of deposition provides an alternative explanation (see Fig. D.1). Further investigations are required to confirm past Ïƒ12subscriptğœ12\sigma_{12}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-resonance episodes in geologic sequences. We propose that future exploration of high-quality and rhythmic sediment successions (especially of Precambrian age) will be critical in constraining the LECâ€™s past stability and hence the history of the solar systemâ€™s chaotic evolution.

Generally, the possibility of an unstable/weak LEC argues strongly for internal consistency checks and tests of eccentricity-related cycles interpreted in stratigraphic sequences at multiple levels. For example, future studies need to include consistency checks between the period of short eccentricity and associated gğ‘”gitalic_g-frequencies and the period of the interpreted (g4âˆ’g3)subscriptğ‘”4subscriptğ‘”3(g_{4}-g_{3})( italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) cycle and/or other very long period eccentricity modulations. At a more advanced level, the internal consistency of all gğ‘”gitalic_g- and sğ‘ sitalic_s-frequencies that can be extracted from the sequence need to be examined, for which algorithms are already available (Meyers & Malinverno, 2018; Olsen et al., 2019). Furthermore, the uncertainty in LEC stability substantially increases the ambiguity in interpreting cycle ratios of the eccentricity-precession forcing. Hence, independent sedimentation rate checks (preferably from accurate radiometric ages) will become inevitable to verify deep-time MilankoviÄ‡ interpretations based on observed stratigraphic cycle hierarchy. Moreover, when significant obliquity signals are present, eccentricity-related cycle pattern will be more difficult to distinguish from those expected for obliquity.

Appendix D Section at Joffre Falls, Western Australia

In the recently discovered Joffre Falls section (âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼2.46 Ga, Western Australia), a dominant short eccentricity cycle was reported (âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼100 kyr) and a relatively weak expression of the LEC (Lantink et al., 2022) (see Fig. D.1). The regular medium-scale (âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼85 cm) alternations of thicker units of banded iron formation and thinner, softer interval of a more shaley lithology (Fig. D.1, left) have been interpreted as the expression of short eccentricity (Lantink et al., 2022). Horizons highlighted in blue (Fig. D.1, left) correspond to cycle numbers in the original log (Lantink et al., 2022) shown on the right. Note the larger-scale modulations in the thickness and relief of the shaley beds (degree of weathering) forming two distinctive darker â€™bundlesâ€™ defined by cycles 17-19 and 23-28. This pattern deviates from an expected strong âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼1:4 bundling pattern or ratio between the medium- and large-scale cycles in case of a strong and stable LEC. (However, note the âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼1:4 ratio visible in the filter amplitude of the bandpass filtered cyclicity on the right.) Higher up in the stratigraphy, the shaley layers become weaker overall and thus any larger-scale modulations are more difficult to recognize. Nevertheless, we count at least 6 medium-scale cycles until the next more distinctive shaley interval, i.e., again no clear 1:4 ratio as would be expected in case of a strong and stable LEC.
